image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: As the government weighs whether to keep or replace Philip Lowe as RBA governor, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton says two key candidates from treasury and finance should be ruled out of the running.

title.children: 'Silly': Former Reserve Bank governor rejects Peter Dutton's suggestion next governor cannot come from treasury or finance

image.altText: Observation cell Banksia Hill

items.synopsis: As more examples of the unlawful confinement of youth detainees come to light, it's time to end the vicious cycle, writes state political reporter Keane Bourke.

title.children: Imagine being locked in a tiny room for days. For these teenagers, it's reality

image.altText: A smiling young man with a beard dressed in high vis pulls a beer from a tap from behind a bar.

items.synopsis: It's a long trek from anywhere, but Ongerup in Western Australia — population 114 — has a community that refuses to let the town die.

title.children: Why this small WA community banded together to buy the pub, supermarket, cafe and petrol station

image.altText: Huw Edwards holding a sheet of paper sitting at a news desk

items.synopsis: The BBC presenter facing allegations he paid a young person thousands of pounds for sexually explicit photos is Huw Edwards, the BBC reports, citing a statement from his wife.

title.children: Highest-paid journalist at BBC, Huw Edwards, named as presenter accused of paying for explicit teen photos

image.altText: A 3D model of the building that burnt down in Surry Hills

items.synopsis: The century-old former hat factory caught fire on a Thursday afternoon. Within seven minutes of the first triple-0 call, the entire building, in the most densely populated part of Sydney, was an inferno.

title.children: Unravelling the inferno that reduced this century-old former hat factory to rubble

image.altText: Putin KGB zelenskyy composite

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin had already proved himself NATO's greatest recruiter, and this week's summit in Lithuania highlights just how heavily sought-after the exclusive club has become, writes John Lyons.

title.children: How the NATO summit showed off Zelenskyy's power and the lingering fear of KGB ideals

image.altText: Fighters of Wagner private mercenary group pose for a picture.

items.synopsis: Russian mercenary group Wagner reportedly hands over its weapons. What's next for the fighters and their leader after June's mutiny?

title.children: Wagner has handed over its weapons to Russia's military. What's next for the mercenary group?

image.altText: Two men, one older and one young, stand wearing Australia Post high-vis gear.

items.synopsis: Michael Richardson has Down syndrome, hearing loss and could not read — but he would not let that stop him landing a job at Australia Post.

title.children: Greg has worked at Australia Post for 17 years, and now his son is following in his footsteps

image.altText: Andrew and Nicola stand side by side on the Perth foreshore

items.synopsis: One of Australia's richest couples announce their separation but insist there will be no impact on their shared ventures, including mining giant Fortescue Metals Group.

title.children: Mining billionaires Andrew and Nicola Forrest announce break-up, insist 'no impact' on FMG operations

image.altText: man with black beanie, brown coat and glasses sits on bed on flatbed ute with pet dog

items.synopsis: In only four months, the Wimmera's only homelessness outreach worker has found more than 60 rough sleepers. Injured abattoir worker Shane is one of them — and the number of people like him is expected to "explode".

title.children: Shane sleeps on a ute tray at night. He pretends he's camping to save face

image.altText: A composite image of Carmy from The Bear, Shiv from Succession and Janine from Abbott Elementary.

items.synopsis: Australia's Sarah Snook is one of multiple Succession cast members to be nominated for an Emmy, with The White Lotus, The Last of Us, and Ted Lasso taking up the other top noms.

title.children: Join us as we chat snubs and surprises in this year's Emmy Award nominations

image.altText: Christopher Eubanks raises his fist and grits his teeth at Wimbledon.

items.synopsis: Christopher Eubanks' dream run may have ended but he has a slice of Wimbledon history it took 30 years to conquer, while Aryna Sabalenka showed her power game is going to be extremely difficult to overcome.

title.children: American rewrites Wimbledon record books in defeat as Medvedev admits to 'dangerous' on court act

image.altText: A man in high-vis and a helmet on an e-scooter on a city street.

items.synopsis: Petition for heavier and more powerful e-scooters in WA after riders call out "unreasonable" laws.

title.children: If you can buy a car that can do 300kph, why not a faster e-scooter? Perth riders push for change

image.altText: A designed image showing John Zeitoune, Jye West and a building bearing an ACU logo.

items.synopsis: The Australian Catholic University has launched an internal inquiry after the ABC discovered the founder of the company providing its on-campus security has been charged with corruption — and had a secret business relationship with an employee overseeing its security contract.

title.children: 'I was told to shut up': Australian Catholic University accused of ignoring concerns about security contractor

image.altText: A man on a bike screams in join as he wins a race.

items.synopsis: Belgium's Jasper Philipsen claims his fourth Tour de France stage win as Australia's Jai Hindley remains in third overall.

title.children: Hindley remains in third overall as Philipsen again proves his sprint class at Tour de France

image.altText: an aerial shot of a 3D printed toilet block.

items.synopsis: A groundbreaking development is taking place in Dubbo, western NSW, that could alter the housing crisis gripping regional NSW.

title.children: 3D-printed toilet block built in a few days could open door to housing solutions

image.altText: A car park at an outback resort with a red cliff in background.

items.synopsis: A resort west of Alice Springs will close while owners negotiate a water pipeline to be built from a bore 18 kilometres away.

title.children: Outback resort closes after water transportation costs make facility economically unviable

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

items.synopsis: The bosses of Westpac and Commonwealth Bank are facing the parliamentary economics committee, a day after ANZ and NAB executives were grilled over interest rates. Follow live.

title.children: Commonwealth Bank and Westpac face grilling over interest rates, US inflation slows, ASX higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Peter Dutton says two of the government's potential picks to replace Philip Lowe as Reserve Bank governor would not be able to operate independently because of their established relationships with government. Treasury secretary Steven Kennedy and Finance secretary Jenny Wilkinson are among the candidates being floated to become the next RBA governor, as speculation mounts over whether the government will extend Mr Lowe's term or replace him when it expires in September. But Mr Dutton said the treasury and finance bosses should be ruled out of the running. "We can't have a situation where the government is appointing somebody who is familiar to the government, in the sense they have worked very closely with ministers, or the treasurer or the finance minister," Mr Dutton said. "We can't have somebody who has been appointed by the Labor Party or indeed the Coalition to a senior position within government. It needs to be somebody who is independent and has the best interests of the Australian public in mind." You can keep reading this story from political reporter Jake Evans below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says two candidates should be ruled out of being considered for RBA governor

featuredLink.title: Peter Dutton says two candidates to become next RBA governor should be ruled out of consideration

children.content: Peter Dutton says two of the government's potential picks to replace
Philip Lowe
as
Reserve Bank governor
would not be able to operate independently because of their established relationships with government.
Treasury secretary Steven Kennedy
and
Finance secretary Jenny Wilkinson
are among the candidates being floated to become the next RBA governor, as speculation mounts over whether the government will extend Mr Lowe's term or replace him when it expires in September.
But Mr Dutton said the treasury and finance bosses should be ruled out of the running.

"We can't have a situation where the government is appointing somebody who is familiar to the government, in the sense they have worked very closely with ministers, or the treasurer or the finance minister," Mr Dutton said.

"We can't have somebody who has been appointed by the Labor Party or indeed the Coalition to a senior position within government. It needs to be somebody who is independent and has the best interests of the Australian public in mind."
You can keep reading this story from
political reporter Jake Evans
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Commonwealth Bank CEO Matt Comyn and deputy David Cohen are in front of a parliamentary committee today. Comyn isn't there in person, he's recovering from COVID and appearing on video. Most of the chat has been about two things: mortgages and scams. Similar to yesterday's bank bosses from ANZ and NAB, they admit there's huge financial stress in society. But this comes with two caveats: the normal indicators like 'not paying bills' are still lower than average and most bank customers (having been able to secure credit or loans) are in better financial positions than a lot of people in society. Here's Matt Comyn. "But absolutely, I feel for and we see very sharply the pressure that many customers are under. As I said, if they don't actually technically answer the financial difficulty or stress, they're definitely making changes to their spending patterns to their circumstances, I'm sure the things that they would otherwise like to be doing or perhaps were able to do before they're having to cut back" Westpac's Peter King is up this afternoon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Scams, mortgages and more: our biggest banker being quizzed right now

children.content: Commonwealth Bank CEO Matt Comyn and deputy David Cohen are in front of a parliamentary committee today.
Comyn isn't there in person, he's recovering from COVID and appearing on video.
Most of the chat has been about two things: mortgages and scams.
Similar to yesterday's bank bosses from ANZ and NAB, they admit there's huge financial stress in society.

But this comes with two caveats: the normal indicators like 'not paying bills' are still lower than average and most bank customers (having been able to secure credit or loans) are in better financial positions than a lot of people in society.
Here's Matt Comyn.

"But absolutely, I feel for and we see very sharply the pressure that many customers are under. As I said, if they don't actually technically answer the financial difficulty or stress, they're definitely making changes to their spending patterns to their circumstances, I'm sure the things that they would otherwise like to be doing or
perhaps were able to do before they're having to cut back"
Westpac's Peter King is up this afternoon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected the Australian share market has opened higher for the day, up 1.3% as of 10:25am AEST. The big gains have come from the materials sector, which is up 0.5%, led by jumps in commodities prices overnight. Consumer cyclicals and financials are both up 0.4% each, and no sector is in negative territory. As for the top five performers, it's unsurprisingly miner-heavy: De Grey Mining +5.1% BrainChip Holdings +4.4% Evolution Mining +4.4% Capricorn Metals +3.9% Domain Holdings +3.6% As for the bottom movers, only Atlas Arteria Group is in the red, down 0.5%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX rises as commodities prices push miners higher

children.content: As expected the Australian share market has opened higher for the day, up 1.3% as of
10:25am AEST
The big gains have come from the materials sector, which is up 0.5%, led by jumps in commodities prices overnight.
Consumer cyclicals and financials are both up 0.4% each, and no sector is in negative territory.
As for the top five performers, it's unsurprisingly miner-heavy:
De Grey Mining +5.1%
BrainChip Holdings +4.4%
Evolution Mining +4.4%
Capricorn Metals +3.9%
Domain Holdings +3.6%
As for the bottom movers, only Atlas Arteria Group is in the red, down 0.5%.
